Anyways, the reason I'm leaving it at 3 stars is because sure, I'd come back -- what else is open so late on a Saturday night in my hood? And they're super friendly and the wait actually isn't that long. But I would probably not come here for lunch or recommend going out of your way to come here.
author: Richa A.

description:
Found this little gem on accident after a night on the dancefloor. Seriously one of the best crepes I've ever had...and I was completely sober! The chicken greek crepe is the one I tried and it was scrumptious. It was healthy yet so good, so no guilty feelings here. Definitely coming back here for my crepe cravings over crepevine :)

FYI: Its like a permanent wooden food truck on the corner. Don't expect any seats here, but definitely worth the wait outside in the cold.
author: Jayme N.

description:
Warm crepes filled with interesting ingredients. Each crepe is a moderate portion size for a healthy, satisfying lunch.

I've eaten at the food stand several times, each time with a different person taking orders. The people who work here are friendly, hip, and good-looking, and usually listening to some funky music on their kitchen radio. There is always a line, because fresh-cooked crepes can't be rushed. The wait is worthwhile. The food is excellent. I would give this place 5 stars if the prices were a little lower.

I've also enjoyed Creperie Saint German for two lunches at work when the cooks brought coolers of ingredients and cooked for us in the office kitchen. This made me happy for the rest of the day.
author: Steve K.

description:
This is my GO-TO spot for something quick, delicious, and nutritious... especially since they now take credit cards! Way to be modern!

I have told all my co-workers about this spot....and highly recommend it. I've only had lunchy types of crepes, nothing sweet yet... 

It's also fun to see their business doing well ever since they accept cards as payment... I'm all for cute, small, independently run spots - especially ones that have awesome food!
author: Karen M.

description:
This little shack occupying barely one parking space in the parking lot at the corner of 2nd and Howard serves up the best crepes. I've been here 6-7 times and every time I'm at awe at what they can whip up in that tiny little space.  Their crepes are made with organic buckwheat.  Healthy, light, and tasty is how I would describe them.  

So far I've tried: the Turkey with sauteed mushrooms, Smoke Salmon with capers/green onions/spinach, bananas with nutella & ice cream, and shrimp with avocado and lime sauce.  All are YUM!  Unfortunately they took  the shrimp with lime sauce off the menu.  I don't know why and I hope they put it back on!
author: Irene T.

description:
I hired Creperie Saint Germain to cater at my home for my daughter's first birthday. It was a huge success and my guests all loved the food and service. Thank you Rick and Z!  

When comparing prices and options with other crepe catering companies, Creperie Saint Germain was very reasonably priced and more importantly for the price offered a huge selection of fresh ingredients so my guests could create their own crepe. This really added to the fun of having crepes at the party.  Other companies only offered you a select number of savory and sweet pre-selected combinations. 

They went above and beyond what I had expected. They quoted me for 1 chef to come and manage 2 hot plates - they brought 2 chefs. They arrived on time and came fully prepared with extension cords and backups for everything including extra batter in case my guest ate more than I had budgeted/ordered.  My party started late and as a result lasted an hour longer than expected. They were kind enough to stay a full hour longer and when it came to settle the bill they did not charged me anything for the incremental time.

I would definitely recommend them to anyone looking for catering and would hire them again in a heartbeat.
author: Angie P.

description:
It's lunchtime in SOMA and you don't want a sandwich. Not today.

You've ruled out Indian food. You had Mexican food the last three days in a row (maybe you live in the mission). 

You'd get curry or noodles, but it'd be too carb-y. Soup is not quite filling enough. Pizza or other italian food is simply too greasy or too heavy. Gyros sound somewhat appealing, if a touch mundane.

That's everything. You've eliminated every feasible SOMA lunchtime food.

Except one. To paraphrase the late Marshall Mathers, "[you]  act like [you] forgot about [Crepes]." 

Creperie St. Germaine brings a suite of savory and dessert crepe concoctions to the figurative table (they are a truck and have no literal tables).

My favorite right now is the "Got Goat" but I'm also partial to the Mediterranean and augmenting any existing crepe with avocados.

The portions are the right size, and the ingredient and flavor combinations will keep you guessing, while tantalizing and delighting your jaded palate. Crepes: they are so much more than the greatest Radiohead song of all time. They're what's for lunch. Today.
author: Alan F.

description:
I tried Creperie Saint Germain for the first time after reading about it in the Chron. I had the "Formidable" Shrimp & Avocado crepe, and it was amazing! A great blend of sweet and savory flavors.

My only complaint is that there is no public place to sit and eat nearby. However, the crepes are packaged in a way that makes them easy to eat while on the move.

I will definitely be back!
author: Dave L.

description:
So, I've eaten a lot of crepes in my lifetime.  Like, a lot of crepes.  I've had hand-held crepes, fancy dinner-type crepes, traditional crepes, fusion crepes, savory crepes, sweet crepes.  You name it, I have probably found it in a crepe and eaten it.  With that background knowledge, I will now make a statement:

Creperie Saint-Germain makes the very best crepes I have ever eaten.

Like, hands down.  The first time I had one of their crepes I bit into it and actually literally thought, "This is going to be the best crepe I have ever eaten."  And then it was.  And then I went back over the weeks and had some more.  And my opinion has not changed one bit.  If anything, every bite of crepe only serves to strengthen my resolve.

Why?  Well, I'll tell you!  For starters, I'm super conscious about eating healthy, and while crepes in general are usually on the short list of things I can eat guilt-free, CSG crepes are made with buckwheat - and that's even healthier!  They mention that.  What they don't mention is that, despite being healthier, it's also the squishiest, butteriest, richest tasting crepe around.  I don't even care what they fill it with, as long as I can eat something that tastes that good and is that good for me.

Except I lied.  I do care what they fill it with.  Which is AWESOME.  They could pretty much change all their menu options to "awesome, awesome, and awesome with awesomecheese" and it would be accurate.  This is definitely not objective at all, but the combinations of ingredients they put in their crepes seem very fresh and innovative to me.  They have a lot of vegetarian options, they have shrimp, they have beef, they utilize turkey in a variety of different ways, and the flavors range from the classic to the creative - goat cheese and jalapeno?  Count me in.  My favorite is the ratatouille, and I pay the extra for the goat cheese; it's totally worth it.  Creamy cheese, creamy eggplant, creamy crepe - and then the crunch of the spinach and green onions.  I just had one not 12 hours ago, and I'm ready for another.

I also really, really like the customer service.  When I've been there, the servers are always really friendly and smiley, and don't even mind making a little small talk if they're not crazily busy. :)

One of the issues that I've come across with is that they do run out of ingredients more often than I might like.  I really don't know how this could be prevented, though, since they're essentially a food stand with a limited amount of space, and are cut off from any sort of larger kitchen.  It definitely pays to have a backup plan if you absolutely don't want your beef to be substituted for chicken, for example.

I also know they don't really do substitutions on request, which would seem odd since they substitute when they run out of things, but not before.  Today I learned that it's because all of their pre-made crepe fillings come pre-mixed.  Fortunately, they also have a really affordable make-your-own option: at other places, custom orders can get pretty spendy, but a custom CSG crepe really isn't too much worse than a regular one.

Also a downside that goes along with being a food stand and not a restaurant is that there's no seating.  But I do find that it's a perfect way to get out of the office around lunch time, take a nice walk, and either bring a crepe back to work or start stuffing my face on the walk back.

CSG is truly my new favorite crepe place and if you like big, buttery-tasting crepes that aren't actually buttery at all, then eating a CSG crepe will be like dying and going to a heaven where skinny, beautiful people alternate playing harps with gorging themselves on crepes.  And be sure to get a stamp card!  Every seventh crepe is free!
author: Becca S.

description: Turkey Egg Cheese was amazing. The crepe skin was soft, chewy, and melted together with the egg and cheese. Pieces of turkey mixed in provided the necessary finish to this amazing savory crepe. At the price of 6.75, this was simply a steal.
author: Edward W.

description:
A new addition to FiDi street food that makes you say "OOh La La!"  The crêpe is made from buckwheat so it is hearty like a galette.  It's also folded into a cone so it's more conducive to eating while standing up as opposed to the traditional knife and fork half moon.  I prefer the half moon shape, but appreciated the cone as a good grab-n-go compromise.  The filling options aren't terribly innovative, but as one of the only crêpe stands around, I don't think they need to get into the business of bulgogi and kimchi filled crêpes like numerous taco joints have started to do in order to have a competitive edge.

Chicken Crêpe: So much for light and wimpy crêpes!  This is a power crêpe filled with chicken, cheese, mushroom, fresh spinach and fresh tomatoes.  It almost feels too healthy for street food.  Thank goodness the chicken and mushrooms are smothered in buttery béchamel else I might be tempted to start doing yoga.

Chocolate & Strawberries Crêpe: Melted scharffen berger chocolate sauce with fresh strawberries... so nice to see this option compared to many crêpe places that get nutella-centric and leave out the chocolate.  The crispy top portion and softer bottom portion made a great texture contrast as I ate my dessert first.
author: Adam B.

description: Number 12 was delicious! But number 18 needed a little bit more caramel  other than that it was yummy! Definitely will be back tomorrow
author: Vinha W.

description:
Quick Review: Filling but not Food Coma status. Good portion for lunch, fair price and tastes pretty good. 

It was one of those unreal movie moments. One day I couldn't figure out what I wanted for lunch. I was actually craving a crepe but I didn't know any place with a good crepe in teh area. I was walking to some sandwich place and I saw a guy walking with a crepe. I ended up getting a sandwich that day. But! while I ate it I yelped crepes in the area and found this place!

A week or two later the crepe craving returned (crepeing?) and I made my way to Creperie Saint Germain.

It's located in the corner of a parking lot and looks like a small bungalow or immobilized food truck. Whatever keeps the overhead down. I felt like a spy when I was ordering because it just doesn't look like a place food is served, but is.

The crepe took some time to be made and there were a few people ahead of me. I had a chicken spinach cheese mushroom crepe and it was good. the mushrooms stood out the most but it all blended well, especially with the buckwheat crepe. Definitely better than if it was a sandwich. Score one for the savory crepes in the sandwich vs crepe battle.

I wouldn't make a trip out of my way to get a crepe here, but I would get some if I was in the area.
author: Glenn M.

description:
Creperie Saint Germain is an extremely convenient crepe place down in the Fi-Di. They're located on the patio area of the Citigroup building on the corner of Sansome & Sutter. Extremely close to the office so it's one of the places I frequent. My favorite is their salmon w/ capers & spinach crepe. It's awesome! They have a ton of other ones and have something for everyone. Their Maya's lover is good too! 

One thing though, when they first started out their crepes were HUGE, and the lines reflected now. Now, not so many lines, and crepe is not as big. Still a good place!
author: Jorge S.

description: It's really 2.5 for me.  The crepe itself needs to be slightly crisper in my opinion.  I've had the savory as well as the sweet.  The savory aren't 'savory' enough.  The Nutella and banana, skimped out on the Nutella, the flavor is not balanced, and therefore not 'sweet' enough.  2.5 for satisfying my hunger but not my taste buds.
author: A T.

description:
We were on our way home from clubbing in SF, when my friend who was driving suddenly yells "There's a crepe stand over there! Can we stop?!" Hungry from clubbing, my other friend and I quickly agree so she pulls over and we rush over to the crepe stand. There was a good size crowd in front of the creperie around 2:30AM in the morning which I took to be a good sign.

Creperie Saint Germain has a lot of choices, with about 20 savory crepes and 20 dessert crepes to choose from. You can also create your own if you don't see your perfect combo on the menu. My friend and I both went for the dessert crepes; she ordered a plain nutella, and I ordered a nutella & strawberries (my favorite!). I've had crepes in France when I studied abroad and one summer I worked in a cafe making crepes, so I like to think that I know a thing or two about them. From my experience with crepes, I can vouch for the ones at Creperie Saint Germain. They are good. The crepe wasn't too thick or too thin and they were generous with the nutella and strawberries. BUT I will say this, they took waaay too long to make. There were 3 people working in the stand, and yet we had to wait 15 minutes for our crepes after we ordered them. Due to their inefficiency, I think they even ended up making a couple orders twice because they made 3 or 4 unclaimed crepes. On the bright side, since no one claimed them, we snagged a cheese, tomato and mushroom crepe for our friend who hadn't planned on getting one. Despite the wait, Creperie Saint Germain was a lucky find and we were all very satisfied with our crepes. What a great late night option!
author: Amy S.

description:
Like many others have noted, this is a small cart and the lines can get really long.  I totally recommend getting here before noon unless you really enjoy standing around industrial block of Howard street.

I didn't time my order (we ordered around 12:15 and ate sometime between 12:30-12:40).  A large group of 6 ordered right after us and they were still there after we got our crepes, walked down a block to a park, ate them and then passed the cart again on our way back to the office.  I don't know about you but I feel like that's a long time.  I felt pretty bad for them.

My other advice is that if you're hungry you should order one of the crepes with meat.  Hubby got the cheese/spinach/mushroom and he was still feeling peckish afterwards.  I got the chicken for only $1 more and I couldn't finish mine.

The crepes themselves were pretty good.  I like how they use actual buckwheat flour like proper French galettes.  The ingredients were fresh but not overwhelming (like that sad excuse for a creperie - Crepevine).  

I was happy I tried this place but since hubby makes pretty good galettes at home I'm not sure how often I'll be stopping by.
author: Jean K.

description: Natascha (who works the truck) is da bomb!  She's super friendly.  Perhaps even more importantly, the savory crepes are delicious. They're the perfect end to an evening of drinking and partying in SOMA.
author: Erick T.

description:
The crepes here are good in so far as everything is very clean and healthy.  It's buckwheat based, so its got plenty of good fiber for you healthy eaters.

I also note that they treated my mushrooms (in my mushroom spinach crepe) as mushrooms should be treated: with a slight bit of butter, and not over sauteed so all the juices come out, and with a bit of crunch still left.

Nonetheless, as much as I like this place, I have to give it only 3 stars because I think the crepe skin should be much thinner!  Sorry, but I have had my fill of crepes in Europe, and any place with a European name should really be able to follow suit.

The quality of the ingredients here is really excellent, however!
author: Mark M.

description:
Wonderful service at this awesome little creperie on wheels. Crepes can be split! All you have to do is let them know when ordering that you'd like to have it split into 2 halves. They'll even wrap them separately. And trust me, you will want to split it with someone. One whole crepe is too much for one person to handle. SRSLY! 

I had the banana, strawberry, nutella, almond crepe with fresh whipped cream. YUM!!!!!!!
author: Jen D.

description:
Ahh, crepes, food of the gods!

Creature of habit that I am, most days you can set your watch to my stately march across the street to this lovely crepe stand.  I get the Mediterranean (Feta Cheese, Avocado, Spinach, Green Onion) every time, it's delicious.

I also have to point out the excellent customer service.  Every time I come, I'm warmly greeted with a smile and my name is remembered.  That goes a long way.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
Had the chicken crepe for lunch the other day - delish!

I'm just glad to have them as a lunch option - adds a certain charm to SoMA.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Perfect after a night out of drinking and dancing. A tad too pricey considering its a food truck but it was a good find nonetheless. 

$7 for a mushroom, cheese, and avocado crepe
$5.50 for a nutella crepe

The girl/guy in the truck looked like they were about to make out so I can only imagine what goes down in there.
author: E. Y. G.

description:
I guess I'm a tough critic especially hailing from France.  The crepes that we ordered was so bland, but i guess to my American friends, they thought it was the bomb.  
Hey, to each their own taste but seriously, this place would not even last in France.  One of our friends ordered the banana dessert crepes, the dough was so bland like eating paper, no taste, flavor or sweetness.  I guess it's a great spot for those who come here after drinking, most people drunk can't really tell if it's really good or not.  
Me being the sober one decided to take a bite and one was enough.  Not my cup of tea but hey, not everyone has the chance to fly to France and enjoy a real crepes.  At least SF, has a crepes stand unlike so.cal where we have Dirty dogs.
author: Peter L.

description:
i am usually hesitant about eating crepes, because there are so many places who do not make them well.  Creperie Saint Germain is not one of those places.  Their Salmon crepes is so good!  Plus the buckwheat batter is delicious and unique.  

I highly recommend this place for good decently priced food.
author: Ally M.

description:
They have buckwheat crepes. Before eating here I knew 2 things about buckwheat:
1. the crunchy pillows
2. dude on Lil Rascals with the big hair

*checks wikipedia. Oh, it's *gluten free*, that's why the coeliac's are jumping on these crepes like white on rice (also gluten free!). 

If you avez les croc, these guys are en plein forme on creperie magie. BON JOUR, BABELFISH!  I had a savory crepe with bacon, shrooms and o's with a little cheese thrown in, bon chat bon rat .

Because they make these à la minute, you will have to wait a bit. So if you're a fusspot who stands around sighing and looking at your watch because your food takes too long, well, then maybe you should bring your lunch to work and stay off the sidewalks. BOTTOM LINE: You will never cry in your cubicle eating a crepe.
author: Francis S.

description:
This place changed my perception of crepes.  I've experienced trauma eating crepes at a different creperie prior to my first visit to Creperie Saint Germain but decided to give this place a chance because of a few recommendations.  

On a cold and foggy night in San Francisco, I happened to check it out with some friends. This place seems to have crazy lines filled with hungry people ready to feast while being eager to engorge the sweet and savory snacks in front of a crepe truck after a long night partying.  

With anticipation of disappointment,  I soon realized that the Savory Chicken Crepe I ordered tastes good.  It had sauteed Chicken with Bechamel Sauce and Mushrooms, Tomatoes and Spinach. The combination of the ingredients complemented well with each other.   I had also tried a Crepe filled with Nutella, Strawberries and Bananas .  The melted hazelnut Nutella with warm strawberries and bananas had reinforced the idea that I should try eating Crepes more often.A bit of the juice from strawberries leaked from the crepe.  As the Carl's Jr. slogan goes "If it doesn't go all over the place, it DOESN'T belong in your face!" 

I tried going back to the crepe truck on another night with some friends, with ridiculous crepe cravings, from out of town to try the awesomeness of this Creperie. The line was longer than last time and did not seem to budge. As we were waiting we had been entertained by some amusing people, such as a stranger with sunglasses that had green lights asking patrons of money.  Eventually hostility arose due to the long wait time and hungry drunk people.  Tensions grew so high that a brutal fight broke out.  It seemed as if multiple fights happening at once, things felt as intense as a scene from the movie Kung Fu Panda but that is just my imagination retelling the story.  No one came in fighting in panda suits.  

I assume fights are not frequently happening in front of a Crepe Truck.  From this recent experience I had my ah-ha moment. I came to the realization that I went from a Crepe Hater to a person who doesn't mind having  crepes from time to time.  

Although some of the girlfriends of the participants in the altercation had repeatedly shouted the words in frustration "It's just for food!"  I knew that deep down, the girlfriends didn't realize that the fighting was not "just for food." 

These truly were Crepes WORTH fighting for! 



Until next time, 

I must try that place again.

DISCLAIMER: No pandas were hurt during the writing of this review.
author: darren w.

description: Wonderful crapes! I plan on visiting the stand each time I come to San Francisco. Each one I have had is amazing, but the Chocolat and Bacon was my favorite!! 5 STARS!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I *heart* their crepes! I saw this little place, researched it on yelp, when to their website and decided to give it a whirl....

1 - Looks are deceiving - I was only a little bit hungry and since I wouldn't be able to eat until 8pm. I thought I'd get something keep me happy for a bit. The size of the crepe on the website looked like it would do. 

The crepes are HUGE! (Yes, I ate ever last morsel! - Now I am paying for it with an extremely full tummy)

2 - I ordered a #9 - Cheese, Turkey and Cranberry. As I stood there and waited for my #9 I wondered if I should have gotten the #8 - Cheese, Spinach, and Mushroom  instead. As my name was called - VIOLA! It was a #8!!!!!  I am digging how in tune he is with the customers.  ;) 

The crepe was huge and yummy. The mushroom and spinach were fresh. I really like the texture of the buckwheat crepe. 

I probably did not need to eat the whole thing but I couldn't stop! This definitely is not a one-time spot for me!  Come on - I still need to try the #9 (and a few others).
author: Deanna J.

description:
Today is a lovely sunny day in San Francisco, plus it's a Friday, so a couple of coworkers and I stepped out to celebrate at "The Crepe Cart," Creperie Saint Germain.  I'm not usually a fan of the street food thing, but crepes are simple enough and I wanted something sweet.  We went around 12:30 pm and there was no line.  (There are also tons of mini-parks and office plazas around so you can sit outdoors to enjoy your crepe.)

I ordered the sugar lemon crepe and my coworkers got a couple of the savory make your own crepes with different variations.  The crepes came out moderately quickly, but I could see how if there were more people things could back up quickly.  My crepe was delish - I kind of wished I'd ordered two!  My coworkers savory crepes were more expensive but absolutely huge, packed with lots of yummy goodies - both looked tasty.  All in all a nice treat during the workweek!
author: Jaimie M.

description:
Good place for lunch when in the financial district. It's around $7.50 a crepe which is average for places around the area. 

I got the chicken crepe which has chicken, bechamel sauce, tomatoes, spinach, and cheese. The spinach wasn't cooked, but overall still a good savory crepe with crispy edges :)

Oh yea, it is cash only.
author: Cindy L.

description:
A few steps from my office, delicious crepes & friendly staff. 

Make sure you bring cash!
author: Amanda R.

description: After downing a few Guinesses down the street at the local Irish pub, we decided to stop by and grub on some crepes. I ended up with the smoke salmon crepe. Surprisingly everything was very fresh. If I recall, it also had capers, cream cheese and lettuce.
author: Kien M.

description: Catered crepes ... my favorite lunch of the month at Pocket Gems!
author: David U.

description:
Marvelous. The crepes were oh-so-slightly crisp at the edges, yet soft and just a tad chewy throughout -- perfection!

I tried two, because I wanted to get a feel of their savory and sweet selections. I had the turkey/cranberry one for the savory, and...well, I'd pick a different one, simply because there wasn't a whole lot of creme fraiche.

The dessert one of strawberries and creme fraiche (again) was marvelous, however.

A little pricey, but well worth it for real crepes. Yay!
author: Cody K.

description:
They're busy and they deal with drunk folks all night long, but still take the time to make a quality crepe from scratch.

I'm a fan of their many vegetarian options and the excellent deal with the stamp card (be sure to ask for it).

Yes, they run out of stuff.  Their cart is the size of a mini-van. There are about 40 different options, and if it doubt, I'd default nutella/banana for something classic but a little bit different to most American palates.
author: Tullia F.

description:
A bit pricey for crepes - mine was $7.50 with nothing too fancy on top, but the quality and portion seem to somewhat justify the premium. 

Whether it's NYC or SF, I totally appreciate the concept of dessert trucks.
author: Derrick P.

description:
I always pass this stand on the way to work and was tempted to try them out. They have a nice selection of breakfast, lunch, brunch and dessert crepes. This is your typical eatery stand on the corner of a parking lot, so during the mid-day it can be as loud as the city traffic around it. 

I tried the Chicken Ceasar Salad crepe and it was fantastic. I think all it was missing was a Ceasar dressing topping to give it the extra kick of flavor it needed to make good to yummy.

Would definitely stop by here again on the way to work if I'm waiting at the bus stop awhile nearby.
author: Terry C.

description: Who knew crepes would hit the spot after a night of drinking? Evidently not a lot of people because I witnessed a drunk dude trying to order tacos at the window. My friend Jamie Q. and I both decided on the #10 Savory Crepe filled with chicken, mushrooms, spinach, tomatoes, and cheese. Since I'm extremely competitive when it comes to eating, I made sure to finish my crepe before my friend was halfway done with hers even though she started eating minutes before I did. I'm pretty amazing.
author: Suany W.

description:
We walk by here on the way back from Harlot and my friend Surbhi starts talking to the guys in the back in Spanish, like "whoah, hold up, how do you know these guys?" Apparently she hits up this crepe stand a lot!

My friend got a dessert crepe with nutella, bananas and strawberries and I got a savory crepe with spinach, mushroom, cheese and avocado. I though it'd be more savory but unfortunately it wasn't. The dessert crepes were pretty tasty though.

Conclusion: If you go here, be sure to order their dessert crepes. I don't think that mine was as savory because they didn't really cook down the veggies - I wish they had! The spinach was uncooked, which was disappointing. 

Because my friend Surbhi likes the people and the stand so much, I'll try this place out again. Perhaps next time will be a better experience!
author: Tisha G.

description:
#22- Maya's Lover..The Maya's lover had tons of beef, beans, jalepenos, cheese, tomatoes, sour cream and avocado! I was in heaven!

Ive never been a fan of savory crepes so I just had to try their most popular and fatty crepe they had! We were in luck and beat the late night crowd before they rolled in. The menu is a bit overwhelming because it is so hard to choose which one I wanted.  Different items such as salmon, tuna, greek, turkey, shrimp, nutella, fruits etc..

I later found out that they use a buckwheat batter. The crepe was soft and chewy with added crunch from the fillings. I like how they did not over cook the crepe. They do not skip out on the fillings either!  You get your orders folded in cone with jucies dripping down your hand. 

Service is ok. The guy is fast at taking orders but making the crepes it does take awhile. Hold your patience, I do think it is worth the wait! I look foward to coming back and trying other things on the menu.
author: Geneve V.

description: I felt SO European eating my crepe in this big marble courtyard for breakfast. What bothered me? That the crepe was pre-made. What did I like? That it was buckwheat. The cheese was really good in this mild way.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Yummy crepes. 
I would eat these every day if I wasn't worried about ballooning to, oh, about 200 pounds!
author: Sarah S.

description:
I wanted to take back my $1 tip. 

While roaming the windswept summer streets of SF for a Friday lunch, I decided to try this mobile creperie. 

I ordered and waited. And waited. And waited some more. I waited so long I was sure I'd been skipped.  I waited so long, I'm sure I could have made some kind of groundbreaking scientific discovery.  And I'm not even a scientist, so that includes the amount of time it would take me to become one.  After 35 minutes of watching other people happily receive food while my stomach growled, I was told they'd run out of one of the key ingredients in my crepe.  Crestfallen, tired, hungry, and grumpy, I decided on a substitute. 

Finally after about 45 minutes of standing on the blustery sidewalk I was handed my compromise crepe with a "sorry for the wait".  It wasn't extra big or extra cheap, or extra anything.  

So how was it?  It was pretty good. Was it worth waiting outside for 45 minutes?  Absolutely not. 

I tipped when I placed my order.  I'd suggest waiting until you get your food to tip.
author: Eli B.

description: I haven't had a crepe for years....so I was super excited to try this place and satisfy my nutella crepe craving!  I ordered the nutella with banana crepe.  I watched the guy make my crepe...he chopped up an old banana and stuck it in my crepe (with the black parts of the banana in my crepe). Luckily he filled the darn thing with so much nutella, that I ignored the fact that the banana was beyond overripe and inhaled my crepe. It was delicious. But not mind blowing. Don't think I will go back.
author: Nicole M.

description: Great caterer.  Really personable, clean, fast, friendly.
author: Zach H.

description:
Crepes to me are Europe, skiing up to a cabin of treats. I have not had that experience here in the states until...... take a wild guess......
Creperie Saint Germain brought me back to those fantastic days.
The crepes made with love care and fresh are what I think of when I want the perfect crepe.
Savory and sweet are both offered and done with outstanding execution and care.

Atmosphere is fun and I promise you a laugh when you are confronted by a blond who is Bonkers!

I recommenced the Mediterranean and the simple yet exciting Ham and Egg.
Nutella a winner every time.

So transport yourself to Europe for 15 minutes and enjoy a crepe.
author: Alain K.

description:
UPDATE - As of 8/6/10 their location has changed. No longer at 546 Howard. Apparently due to construction around the TransBay Terminal, they had to move. We heard they'll be somewhere around 2nd street.

Good crepes, always get the banana + nutella as an afternoon snack. Cash only.
author: Ryan D.

description:
I'm impressed.  Really.
I've walked by this tiny little cart for more than a year, and I've heard really good thing about it.  But I've never been.  That is, until today.  I finally gave it a shot.  Now I'm kicking myself for not trying it a year ago.

I got the Chicken crepe.  It was flavorful.  There spinach was fresh.  

I can actually see myself visiting this place daily to try every single one of their crepes.
author: Marc E.

description:
I'm coming out of my yelp coma to write a review of my favorite lunch spot in the FiDi/ SOMA nexus.

Creperie Saint Germain is a rather formal sounding name for a crepe truck that stands next to a freeway and a makeshift home for two homeless people.  But it is a magical truck, comprised of a wonderful woman that knows my name and delicious goodies.

To date, I've had the salmon crepe, which is absolutely awesome and very hearty, and the cheese, tomato, and mushroom crepe-- which is to die for!  They were both well prepared, well seasoned, and probably the best crepes I've had (relative to Crepes on Cole, the Crepe house, and squat & gobble).

Go there, get a reward card (buy 5 crepes, get the 6th free!), and be prepared to wait for a while during the peak times (maybe as long as 10 - 15 minutes) for the best crepe of your life.
author: Julie L.

description:
We were at Barracuda (80's Night) at Minna and  got successfully tipsy there.  Since we couldn't drive we wandered around the block looking for food.  Thank you yelp for having a mobile app because the 3 or us went on a scavenger hunt around the neighborhood looking for this restaurant.

We were surprised to find a little cart type stand on the street corner.  I don't remember both crepes we got but one of them was the ratatouille crepe which was delicious.  When you've been drinking, everything tends to taste great but I think this would have been great sober too.

The girl taking our order was also very sweet and handled my friend, who was hitting on her the whole time we were there very graciously.  :)
author: Rosalind S.

description: Late night crepes in SOMA? Awesome. Extremely delicious, just need to try sober to confirm!
author: Alice A.

description:
Went here for lunch and got #12, egg, turkey, extra cheese.  I changed my order slightly and swapped the extra cheese for some spinach yum.  The order didn't take too long so that was good, though I've seen way more people out here before.  Got there about 12:30PM.

Bringing the crepe back was a little awkward as there is nothing covering it up.  I don't know, it just felt weird knowing people seeing my food.  Plus on my way back to the office I was dodging little white puffy seeds in the air.  Don't get into my food nature.

Anyways, as I was walking back, I didn't notice where the egg was started to search through the crepe.  Giving up, I took a bite into the crepe and was happy to see that the egg was in between the crepe layers.  Sneaky of them.  All in all the crepe was delicious and I can't wait to try the desert ones.
author: Davey L.

description:
Hot and cold: experience and product.

It's one of those cycles: "place looks decent, clean, supposedly has good ingredients. Let's try it." Service is fine, a little lackluster, but fine. The food is often slapdash and shows it. Mixed hot and cold (temperature), too soupy, crepes inconsistently thick. 

So, you get burned, time passes, then you think again "it wasn't that bad, was it?" It was. It is.

Also, the wrapper is nearly impossible to tear without flopping the crepe ingredients hither and yon. Most places have a very lite wrapper. Here, it's one step away from card stock.

Note to self, and others: amble up Kearny and have a good banh mi for half the price.
author: Keith P.

description:
Today in a haze of starvation I wandered past this crepe truck and thought to myself "hmn, that sounds like an interesting lunch." It was DIVINE. 

I got a ham, pineapple and cheese crepe that quite honestly made my day. Crepes from a truck. Will wonders never cease? I want to go back and try ALL of them - the menu has great options!
author: Amber C.

description:
This is a ginormous crepe. Absolutely HUGE.

We got bananas, coconut, chocolate, almonds, whipped cream and I think that's it. If you like crepes stuffed with goodies, this is your kind of crepe.

It's the size of a slice of Costco pizza.
author: Beverly T.

description:
I've been staring at the crepe stand for a week before I finally decided to give it a try.  I had heard people complaining about the thickness of the actual crepe, when I tried it I was like....jigga what?  That sh*t was so good!  I've been twice and will continue to go because I love it.  They earn bonus points from me for offering Nutella AND Chocolate - that is the first time I've seen that.  They have a fairly unique menu.  I've had both a savory crepe and then I tried the Chocolate crepe, which I'll be getting later on.

They are cash only, so make sure you've got some cash on you.
author: Sonya T.

description:
Here for business and found this on Yelp when I had a craving for crepes.  Like everyone said already - ultimate street food and perfect for breakfast when I'm on the run.

They put so much stuff in mine - egg, ham and cheese.  And my friend had avocado, mushroom and cheese - not sure how it taste but looked really good.  

In the winter it only opens until 3:30 pm so need to make sure I run over to get a next dessert crepes for tea time!
author: Anne L.

description:
This place is amazing. Delicious crepes, great variety, and reasonable prices. I've tried the chicken, salmon, and greek- all have been savory and fresh.

They also come wrapped very neatly, no worries about having it drip from the bottom or ingredients spilling out of the top.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Lily T.

description:
Ever since my trip to France several years ago, I've developed a fond appreciation and love for crepes. Alas, I came across this adorable little crepe cart after my first day of work and I've been dying to try it out ever since. Fast forward 2 weeks and I find myself debating over which savory crepe to order. 

There's a large variety of sweet and savory crepes including many unique combinations (like smoked salmon with capers, sugar and lemon, chestnut spread, etc).  You can even customized your own crepe!

I'm one of the most indecisive people when it comes to picking what to eat.  After debating for several minutes, I decided on the savory rataouille crepe which is filled with onions, spinach, eggplant, and goat cheese (an add-on). The crepe looked delicious and they definitely didn't skimp on the fillings. 

The crepe was hearty, filling, and thankfully, didn't make me feel weighed down. I liked that it's a healthier alternative to typical street-food. 

However, what disappointed me about the crepe was its texture. I would have preferred a crisper crepe to compliment, for lack of a better word, the mushy texture of the vegetables inside. Come to think of it, caramelized onions would have been THE perfect addition since it would provide a much-needed "crunch factor." Additionally, the spinach wasn't, surprisingly, not cooked and the vegetables needed more seasoning (salt or pepper). 

On the other hand, the service is great. The guys are lively, funny, and really nice. I even got a free sample of the chestnut spread while I was waiting. 

Overall, I had a pretty good/decent experience with this place. For the price I paid ( more than $8), I got a mediocre crepe. Nonetheless, I'll probably visit the card again. But from now on, I'm going to stick with  classics like nutella with whipped cream (yummm). 

And AWESOME news:  The truck will now be open Friday's and Saturdays from 8pm-4am. YES, until 4 am. This seems like a perfect place to satisfy late-night cravings after a night out in a nearby club/bar
author: Clarissa T.

description:
This is one of those places where I have to wonder how it has a 4 star rating. There are much better crepes in SF. Maybe the 100+ people here have never had crepes before.

Here's my experience at Creperie Saint Germaine:

- I ordered #22 - the Maya (beef, beans, jalapenos, cheese, tomatoes, sour cream and avocado). After submitting my order they tell me they are out of beef, but they will substitute chicken. Not a big deal, but a little annoying.

- Apparently they also ran out of beans and jalapenos (but didn't tell me) because there was none to be found in my crepe.  So I pretty much had a buckwheat crepe with chicken, cheese, tomatoes, sour cream and avocado.  The crepe was so bland. It left me completely unsatisfied.

- Crepe in a cone shape = great idea. Except for the fact that all the juice sinks to the bottom and you end up with a soggy messy. Gross.

Verdict: It was fun to try a new place for lunch, but I won't be coming back.
author: Lara O.

description:
Mmmmmmmm.  Can you ever really go wrong with crepes?  I've never gone to a crepe place - mobile or otherwise - and left thinking, "blech, those crepes were disgusting."  They are pretty rock solid when it comes to allison-tummy-satisfaction.

What I particularly loved about Saint Germain's was the buckwheat batter itself.  Crispy, delicious - I might even like this better than the regular stuff.  For about $7-8 a pop, this is a great option in the lunchtime rotation, nestled right between my banh mi and organic fancy-pants salad.
author: Allison B.

description:
Since I moved to San Francisco from New York City, I was very disappointed to find an utter lack of street food in San Francsico. When I finally came across this stand on my way to work, I was delighted to finally see another cart in my new city. 

There's an excellent and diverse selection of ingredients including some rather unorthodox options such as Salmon with cream cheese. I had a savory cheese, egg and smoked turkey breakfast crepe that I found surprisingly hearty and filling. The whole thing tasted a little salty in some places and a little bland in others, but overall I would say it was pretty good and I would definitely stop by here again.

I'll definitely give the sweet crepes a try next time.
author: Tian X.

description: Oh man! My crepe was obscenely large and in charge! Overstuffed with my toppings (my fault, I always get too many) I nearly ruined my outfit before a meeting. Delish though. You must try one. The peeps who work the cart are super nice too.
author: Nicole O.

description:
It's ok.... but it doesn't compare to the most basic French crepes found on any corner in Paris...
I got a lemon and sugar crepe- it had little sugar, little lemon, but several seeds...
author: Tasha R.

description:
smoked salmon crepe w/ cream chs, green onions, capers and spinach - oh so good. it set me back about $10, which is a little more than i'd like for a take out lunch, but it was filling and awesome. she didn't scrimp on the salmon either.

also, pls get the square. having cash is so rare.
author: Elise B.

description:
I'm really glad I didn't have any groceries in the house today. I might not go grocery shopping for awhile, just so I can have an excuse to go here again.

This place just moved even closer to my office - which is great, or dangerous if you love Nutella as much as I do. Once, when I was in a bad mood, my boss went and bought me a crepe with Nutella to cheer me up. How awesome is that?

Today, I was leaning toward the savory side, so I got an egg, cheese and spinach crepe. Wow, that thing was good. And huge! I couldn't even finish it, and that says a lot, because I'm normally not one to leave food behind. They do use a boatload of cheese - next time I'd ask for way less, but it sure was delicious. The guy working there was really friendly - I mentioned that my heels were sinking into the dirt out front, and he said they'd just removed a tree and that it would be fixed soon. Not to worry, hungry, stiletto-wearing ladies of San Francisco!

This is a great spot for a breakfast to grab and bring into the office, or lunch, or hey, I hear they're even open late night! It does take a few minutes to make your crepe - but that's because it's made fresh, and worth the wait. I'd definitely recommend splitting it with a friend (another review says they'll even split it for you!) or having half for breakfast and half for lunch, maybe with a nice little side salad. Yes, I like this plan! I know what I'm having for lunch later this week.
author: Janet G.

description:
First off, a disclaimer: I dropped in my business card and got a free crepe, so I'm biased.

That being said, the thought of savory crepes never appealed to me, I've even been to Paris 3 times and never tried one. But, someone said I should try this place, and I now see the error of my ways, there things are DELICIOUS!

I particularly recommend the chicken crepe which has this crack-like Bechamel sauce that's pretty much pure buttery yum-ness. If you're ever around 2nd and Howard, check them out.
author: William W.

description:
I usually pass this place on my way to Chipotle for lunch. Well--I wasn't really in the mood for the usual barbacoa burrito so decided to make a closer stop & try one of their crepes. Y U M.

So glad I discovered this place as they are delicious. I have tried both the make your own as well as the ones on their menu. Everything tastes so fresh (my favorite part). I usually don't get to the office before I start devouring my avocado, bacon & mozarella cheese crepe.
author: Yishra L.

description:
I finally came across it when it was open, figured out that they open weekday early and weekends late. The buckwheat batter is unique and the stand just smells so amazing while you are waiting for your crepe... =9

It's cash-only and an average savory crepe runs about 8 bucks
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Went there Friday for a breakfast crepe of spinach, feta and egg in a buckwheat crepe. I ordered this combination because Starbucks has it as a  breakfast wrap and I like Starbuck's version. 

St. Germaine's is a bit different. It is fresher and tastier I am happy to say. The spinach is fresh and leafy, the feta is liberally placed throughout and the egg is not too obtrusive. A nice combination of flavors but the buckwheat crepe is the coup de grace. Very tasty. 

I will return for more.
author: Mark K.

description:
My wife and I, after a night of clubbing at the Temple, were super hungry. Conveniently located near the club, it was our only resort. We went there with a little bit of apprehension (yeah well, it is a trailer). 
We ordered a cheese, tomato and sauteed mushroom crepe at 2AM. And to our miserable luck, we didn't have cash on us. Just $3 in cash.
The guy was really nice to us and accepted just that $3 and gave us the crepe without cutting short on any of the ingredients and with a big smile. And, the crepe was one of the best I have had in a while. I am definitely going back there.
Thanks a bunch guys!!!
- Arun
author: Ranjani S.

description:
I'm normally disappointed by crepes. Crepevine, crepe place on Haight, Melt...all leave me underwhelmed and with a dry sticky feeling on the top of my mouth. WTF is that about?

Creperie Saint Germain on the other hand, now they know how to make a damn good crepe! I had the Mediterranean yesterday and it was GREAT. Avocado, feta, fresh tomato and other vegetables, pepper, some oil and vinegar I think. It was delicious. I wish my friend JL would have informed me that chicken was an option (or that I read the menu more carefully) because I would have thrown that into the mix. 

Do yourself a lunch or dessert favor (the sweet ones are awesome as well) and come here! They are open til 7. Heck yeah!
author: Jackie M.

description:
Love how there is a crepe place near my work.  Friend ordered the # 22 Maya and I ordered # 13 Got Goat.  The wait was a little long, but it was all good once I got my gigantic crepe in a cone.  Immediately without biting into it, you can tell the ingredients (spinach and tomatoes) were very fresh.  Lots of delicious goat cheese and wow, lots of spicy diced jalapenos.  I loved how crispy the crepe is on the edges.  Not to mention it being buckwheat crepe too, so it's healthier.

I definitely would want to order their Maya after seeing how much beef, avocado, cheese, etc they pile into that crepe.  My friend's expression says it all, she was one happy camper and I was sold to get that next time.

Note that this place is cash only.

Creperie Saint Germaine will definitely be in the lunch and late night mix.
author: Yun W.

description:
Woo-Hoo! Finally a crepe place near my work! Walked by it today after lunch and had to do my Yelper's duties and check this place out. The findings: Great satisfaction. 

I ordered a crepe with Nutella, Bananas and Strawberries. The crepe itself was great. Soft and only crispy on the edges, just like the ones they made in Paris. If you have been following my reviews, you know that I'm a Francophile and I know my crepe. This one is a keeper. Even though I had already had some tacos for lunch, but the crepe was so good, I ate it all. Yeah! I'm a bit of a pig some time (ok, most of the time, you happy now?) 

My only complaint -- please use fresh whipped cream instead of the canned stuff. Trust me, the flavor and texture are so much better and you can dress up the whipped cream with different flavors like vanilla beans or orange zests and Grand Marnier. Just a thought! 

Other than that, good crepe, good prices, good services and obviously good location since is only 2 blocks from my work! Score! They also have savory crepes, which I will go back to sample. Merci!
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
The HUGE Ratatouille Crepe is deserving of 5 stars. I think all their savory crepes come with cheese but, they don't list so on the menu. So, if cheese is not your thing then, just let them know not to put cheese in your crepe while ordering.

The wait can be taxing. But, the crepe is well worth the wait. Cash only. No seating in sight. Make sure to take some extra napkins.
author: Tushar V.

description: Super tasty and feels so much healthier than street food.  I had the #10, substituting goat cheese for the parmesan, and it was delicious.  My lunchtime crepe was served up in just a few minutes at the peak lunch hour of 12:45.
author: MA f.

description: Love how this place is right at the corner of the SF apartment.  And it's open super late! So I usually pick up a snack after dinner and movies and on the way back home.  Their dessert one with nutella and banana is to die for.  It can get real messy though, so not something you can eat and walk at the same time.  I mean you can, but just be prepared for some accidents.
author: Mei C.

description: I think my eyes were rolling to the back of my head as I was enjoying a crepe from here last night. OMG this place could easily become a horrible late night, after-bar addiction..lol
author: Cassandra E.

description:
This is bad. This is very, very bad. There is a crepe truck around the corner from work and they've got some good quality crepes.  If I had any hope of maintaining my so-called summer diet, it's certainly been crushed now. It doesn't help at all that the crepes are significantly cheaper as a lunch option than some of the surrounding establishments.  

Maybe not the most authentic crepes, but who cares? They're good.  Though, I might go with the simpler menu items.  I got the crepe with ratatouille and spinach and all I could taste was the overwhelming taste of eggplant.  Once I got to just the crepe and cheese, it was delicious, though.  

Also, the crepes are pretty big.  Just know that before you consider getting both a savory and sweet creep.  And it's cash only.
author: Alea G.

description:
Food trucks apparently are the new in thing right now!  I headed over Creperie Saint Germain (which is parked half a block from where I work) when one of my coworker friends said he wanted to try it.  

The first thing that I notice is that they actually make their crepes to order!!!  So many times have I've seen crepes made in bulk and reheated when they are ordered...shame shame.  

Not only are the crepes made to order, they are organic and healthier because made with buckwheat batter (extra pluses). 

I got their chicken crepe with bechamel sauce, mushroom, fresh spinach, and tomatoes.  The crepe was great!  They didn't skimp out on the fillings and I was able to taste every component inside.  Yum yum.  I'll be sure to check out their other crepes soon!

P.S.  The crepe does get drippy from the filling near then end so make sure you finish the crepe over a napkin!
author: Alex T.

description:
This place can be hit or miss. My first experience, I was dazzled! But the last time, my crepe wasn't heated up enough and the cheese wasn't melted. My boyfriend's had tin foil wrapped INSIDE the crepe! But usually you get a hot tasty crepe good for a quick lunch on the run. One isn't totally filling, but two would be way too much. They make such good crepes for such and itty bitty truck!

Try the turkey-cheese-cranberry, or the tomato-spinach-cheese.
author: Halley B.

description:
The strawberries and bananas were unripe, the person preparing my crepe appeared unfamiliar with good knife technique, and the crepe was folded in a way that made it awkward to eat by hand (which is essential for take-away food).  I've had way better in San Francisco's Japan Town and on Clement St.

EDIT:
Today was the second time my company catered crepes from Creperie St. Germain, and it was the second time that it was very dissapointing.  Though the crepes are made to order, the printed menu suggested a handful of "recipes" so I selected one of the sweet crepes, "Nutella Something-or-other":  Nutella, "Fresh" Strawberries, Bananas, "Creme Chantilly", and powdered sugar.  Well, again, the strawberries were white, hard, flavorless, and not exactly "fresh."  The bananas were non-existent.  Even though they had JUST SET UP and I was one of the first in line, I was told they were "out of bananas."  :-|  I heard one of the staff suggest getting bananas from the nearby Safeway.  That's fine, but I wasn't aware my premium crepes get their produce from the local supermarket.  Then, the person making my crepe didn't know what went into the crepe and kept asking me, even though there are only 5 ingredients (now down to just 4), and even though it's one of the "suggested crepes."  Also, in case you're wondering, "Creme Chantilly" is actually just Redi-Whip from an aerosol can.  Again, like last time, the crepe was prepared and folded amateurishly.  And again, like last time, all the crepes themselves were pre-made and in a cold stack.  

This is ridiculous.

There are crepe places in San Francisco's JapanTown and on Clement St. where high school kids crank out delicious, hot, fresh crepes with more panache and less pretension, and for less money.
author: D Y.

description:
What??  No gluten free batter?  It's says you have it on your menu, and when I call Sansome they say each location should have it.

I went to Metreon on a Friday - no GF batter
I went to Howard & 2nd on a Wednesday - no GF batter
I went to Howard & 2nd on a Monday - success! (and mighty delicious)
I went to Howard & 2nd on a Tuesday - no GF batter
I went to Metreon on a Friday - no GF batter

Really, Creperie Saint Germain, I want to eat your crepes!
author: Michelle L.

description: I wasn't a huge fan of the buckwheat crepe, but I did like the filling. I got the ratatouille one with eggplant, spinach, onions and cheese. I like how it came out like an ice cream, which made it portable to my eating spot. It was oh so delicious and just the right amount for lunch. It didn't give me the food coma afterwards.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Creperie Saint Germain AKA the crepe roach coach (without the roaches)  on the corner of the parking lot. I really enjoy their crepes, they have some pre-built but if you really want to get the most out of the experience you should make your own. Their staff has always been nice to me and have always stuffed my crepe to the brim with toppings. They have dessert crepes and savory crepes. I typically stick to the savory crepes and load up on their toppings before hitting one of the bars/nightclubs that are just a block away. This place is very vegetarian friendly with loads of non-meat options. Apparently all of their batter is wheat based and their toppings are fresh. A pretty healthy fast-food option altogether.

The only real con of this place is that there is NO seating. Honestly if this place had some seating I would give it 5 stars but it's just a bit too big of a con to overlook. The best place to sit is at the bus stop (that has an overhang) about 20 feet away. Not that walking to a bus stop to eat your delicious crepe is a problem, it's just doesn't guarantee that you will have a place to sit.
author: Nate S.

description: There are better lunch options in the area, but this place is awesome for late night. Tasty, interesting crepes at reasonable prices. I'm generally surprised they have as many ingredients as they do, and especially considering it is usually just one person here, the line isn't too bad. Cool spot.
author: Karl N.

description:
I have worked in SoMa for four years and I can honestly say that Creperie Saint Germain's Greek crepe is the most delicious thing I have purchased for lunch from any restaurant around here.  The crepe itself is the perfect mix of crispy and soft, savory and sweet - and, when paired with feta, sundried tomatoes, caramelized onions, fresh spinach and pine nuts, it tastes absolutely divine.  

I really wish they would take this cart away from here so I wouldn't be so tempted to frequent it as often as I do...
author: Jessica H.

description: Now  I would recommend this over Sushiritto anyday! Quick/friendly service - cheap prices for crepe sandwiches - I had the mushroom veggie and it was delicious - it took three/five minutes to make.  Not premaid and no mayo crap..... it was light, tasty and filling.  Its a food crepe truck that serves quality/tasty restaurant style crepes at cheap price on the go! Check it out!
author: Lar G.

description:
Creperie Saint Germain is great.  The crepes are just the right size and surprisingly really filling.  The chicken number 10 is really the best, and some of the other combinatins are a bit strange but they let you make your own so there is something for everyone.  

There isn't really anywhere to sit so these are better on a warm day.
author: Julia B.

description:
My vanpool drops me off about 2 blocks from csg and i am forever walking past the cart and wishing that i were not perpetually running late for work.  It smells frigging delish!  so, in honor of Bastille Day, my friends and i decided to finally sample their delicious buckwheat wares...we were not disappointed.  

I ordered the #20..chicken with bechemel, mushrooms, tomatoes, cheese and raw spinach.  soooo yummy!  the chicken had a great flavor and there was only a little bechemel, so it wasnt overpowering the other ingredients.  Add to that the fact that t he crepe itself was crispy on the edges and nice and soft as you got to the middle....mmmm perfection!

One of my friends go the smoked salmon with capers and she loved it, too.  My other friend ordered the turkey cranberry, but got the ham pineapple ( the cause for the -1 stars).  Although she haaaaates pineapple (because she's obviously very wierd...pineapple is the 2nd best fruit of all time), she said the crepe was delicious once the offending fruit was discarded.  

The only sucky thing about csg is that it is located near what i somewhat fondly refer to as bumsville, and there was a lovely young crackhead discussing (on his imaginary cell phone made out of his finger) why chinese people should be shipped back to their own country because they are trying to get into tyra bank's life too much...ahhhhh bumsville.
author: Rena H.

description:
Went here for the first time this week.  Ordered a savory crepe of mushrooms and chicken for $6.  It was really delicious.  I don't know what kind of mushrooms were used in the crepe but it was very good.

When you go here you gotta have a bit of patience as you won't get the crepe immediately.  It's not a fast food truck.  It's worth the wait if you have the time of spare.
author: Thang H.

description: Had a chance to talk to "Z" (or is that "Zee") the lovely woman who opened this creperie truck next to Temple about her first day. It's taken 8 months and 15 different permits and subsequent inspections to open what amounts to a small trailer with 2 crepe griddles. Wow. That's insane. We should all flock to her buckweat creperie if only to help her recoup her costs. She's open from 6am and closes at 3am. Yummy crepes for breakfast, lunch, dinner, dessert, and post party. Average price around $6.50. Totally worth it.
author: Jared H.

description: Decent crepes, not the best, and definitely a bit over priced considering they are often under-stuffed.
author: Jon M.

description:
It should have been a routine new-neighborhood exploratory mission.  Except that a meeting I was to chair was to start in ten minutes and I had absolutely no idea where I was in relation to my starting point (the office), and still hadn't picked up something for lunch.

So stumbling across Creperie Saint Germain was a lifesaver, as I was able to munch a deliciously rejuvenating spinach, mushroom, cheese crepe while looking for the office, and not dribble anything on my front.

I regret not managing to leave a trail of foil scraps, as a nutella crepe would have been an excellent reward for having hosted that meeting.
author: Mutant O.

description: this was a great snack while visiting sf! however, plan ahead because they close at 4pm most days.  While there, I got the #13 crepe which was kind of a huevos rancheros type crepe. I wish they had more goat cheese!!!!
author: Peter N.

description: We all know the claim of "healty" crepes is a joke & a horrible typo on their signage.  Besides that, the Creperie is excellent.  I ordered a nutella & Strawberry crepe, it came topped with a mound of whipped cream.  For $6.50 this is one of my better cheap treats while visiting San Fran.  Bonus: it's across the street from my hotel, Courtyard Downtown.  The savory options looked great, I may have to try them for breakfast.
author: S B.

description:
I followed my nose to this little trailer cart looking thing a few nights ago, and thought I would be in for a ride of my life with the line being decently long. They offer both savory and sweet crepes. How nice! So many choices for such a small little stand like this! My boyfriend and I both got a savory crepe which is made with buckwheat. 

I had the breakfast crepe which has bacon, eggs, and cheese. My boyfriend ordered the ham, egg, and cheese. Pretty darn similar ingredients, so we'd think we'd get our food about the same time. Nope. I understand there were a lot of people waiting for their crepes as well, but why would my crepe come out first, and then we'd have to wait for the people behind us to get their crepes, before the dude realize we didn't get our other order? Fine. We'll let that pass... but then... the moment of truth.. the taste. mine wasn't bad, it wasn't great, but it wasn't awful. the buckwheat crepe overpowered my bacon and cheese. how does that happen? those two things are salty??? My boyfriend's ham and cheese crepe was to say in nicer words, meh. the cheese wasn't melted (since they forgot our order) and the ham was cold. 

I really want to be understanding and give them the benefit of the doubt because they are a two man machine and the crowds are big there. but if that's the case, maybe offer less items or get another dude on board.
author: My C.

description: By far the happiest Frenchwoman I have ever met outside of France, she put a smile on my face today, made me want to quit my job and join her in this little cart! Whether you are looking for Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner Dessert or a quick snack...a crepe is always necessary. We stopped for a Strawberry, Banana & Nutella Crepe and it was Killer! And a lot of people on the street were totally jellybeans that we had a crepe and not them. Such, a good idea. $15 for two crepes. Bring your cash.
author: Sarah M.

description: Meh, just okay. Ordered the #17. Beef reminded me of sloppy joe's from elementary school.
author: Anthony K.

description:
This review is for the dessert crepe only.

I always walk by this crepe cart/stand on my way home and I have never seen it open.  Then one late night I saw the lights lit up and a small line around the sidewalk, I knew I had to get a crepe right there and then!  I got the #29 crepe with Apple Sauce, Crème Fraiche, Cinnamon, Almonds, and Caramel Sauce.  Since I'm a fatty I also added a scoop of vanilla ice cream on top.  Yes did I mention it was also midnight?  

When I got my crepe the vanilla had almost completely melted WTF?!  I understand that the crepe is freshly made so it's a little warm, but ice cream melting to the point that it becomes vanilla sauce?  That's kind of unacceptable.  Add that on top of the apple sauce and the creme fraiche, it was just a big, creamy, runny mess.  This then made the crepe itself extremely soggy.  It was just a disaster to eat, to say the least.  On top of that, the crepe was very thick, almost like some kind of chewy pancake texture.  Not at all like the thin crepes with slightly crispy edges that I love.  

Maybe the savory crepes are better, but I will never know because I will never go back again.
author: Nancy J.

description:
The salmon crepe has told me all I need to know about this place.

Buckwheat batter, salmon, capers, green onion, and spinach.  Amazing.  I will be back for the rest of the menu.
author: Jeff S.

description:
A different kind of crepe. Well at least in my limited crepe experience.  They are great if you are on the run and it was the first crepe I ever ate without utensils.  I certainly liked the many options offered of savory and sweet. So many options that it actually took me a little bit of time to decide. 

The service was fast and friendly. Pretty typical for a truck. All in all though, I'm not sure if I would go out of my way to come here but since I work in the neighborhood I will definitely return.
author: Roger H.

description: Sugar & butter crepe. Or nutella. Awesome & friendly guys working there :)
author: Yasmin M.

description: I had a savory crepe for lunch.  I like the taste and the portion size is perfect for a light lunch.  There will be a bit of wait since they make it after your order.   However, it probably takes less than 10 minutes and I can eat it as I walk back.  (I know it's bad manner but the crepe smells and taste great.)
author: Steven M.

description:
Yes, what they said.

I had cheese, ham, and pineapple. It was delicious. I also enjoy that they fold them as cones. Much easier to eat.

Also, they open at 7am and close at 10pm. This is awesome.
author: Patricia E.

description:
Just back from my virgin voyage to this crepe truck.  I created my own, so I guess the rating is somewhat of myself....

"Then how can it not be a 5-star???"
"There are people reading this, you know?"
"Oh, sorry..."

Anyway, I ordered a ham, spinach (which is fresh), sauteed mushroom, feta & goat cheese.

YUM-MEE!  And filling!  The crepe itself was a tad crispy which was OK by me and the fresh leaf spinach has me feeling a bit better psychologically (diet wise).   Like most other lunch spots, go before Noon if you want to avoid a line.  Plus they probably only have 2 or 3 pans so they can only go so fast.  I didn't heed my own advice today but no worries as it's gorgeous outside.  

Definitely a welcome addition to the area.  I hope they're parked there for a while!

PS - Yelp "Additional Tips" questions need to adapt to food carts/trucks (Attire?  Waiter Service?)
author: John K.

description:
the classier, fresher, higher quality version of crepes-a-go-go!!!

the [savory] crepes here are even MORE cheesy, loaded, and amazing. the menu is soo exciting. the crepe batter they use is wheat based. and please get #11 - cheddar cheese, turkey breast, caramelized onion, creme fraiche, mushroom. - oh myy god. i also couldn't stop staring at the one with goat cheese, or the one with smoked salmon. when i am buzzed late at night and i see such mouthwatering creations so readily accessed, you do not know how excited i get. but i'm sure i would also come here on a regular basis. and i have no doubt their sweet crepes are just as delicious. crepe-gasm!
author: Jessica C.

description: crepe was good - got the special with asparagus and cheese, was very tasty.  Lots of people waiting when i got there and took quite a while to get my crepe...
author: p v.

description: The food was tasty, but they didn't have any of my top options available- salmon, shrimp, or tuna.. so I got a crepe with olives, feta, spinach and tomatoes. Not a bad 4th choice, but I probably won't be back. Interesting options/variations, and definitely a good choice for the meat eaters.
author: Lara M.

description: I've probably walked by this little cart about two dozen times on my way to eat somewhere else. I was craving something sweet and paid CSG a visit. The girl who took my order was super friendly. Everything sounded good, but I settled on a strawberry nutella crepe. My name was called and boy was I excited. I planned to walk back to work (3 looooong blocks) and take pictures when I got into the office. Well, I made it back to the office but my crepe didn't. As I reached the front door I realized I had nothing left. Oh well, this only means I have to go back. Poor me.
author: Adelina W.

description:
Yum yum yum! My office is about half a block from this wonderful crepe stand, and I eat there a couple of days a week. Their buckwheat crepes are light and crispy (not spongy or doughy, which drives me nuts.) and the fillings are super fresh. Creperie Saint Germain offers a variety of sweet and savory crepes - my staple is a crepe stuffed with baby spinach, mushrooms, turkey, and gooey cheese. 

The woman who runs the counter is unbelievably nice. 

It's hard to tell if I love them so much because they're so convenient, or because the ingredient combos they offer are what I generally crave, or because the crepes are so damned tasty. It's probably a combo of all three. 

My only complaint is that I almost never have cash (Saint Germain is cash-only) so I often have to wander past the stand, find an ATM, and wander back. You'd think I'd have learned by now.
author: Sara A.

description:
pretty close to the perfect lunch.

thin, crispy, "buckwheat-alicious" crepe enveloping all of my favorite things. like ham. like goat cheese. like spinach. and tomatoes. the best part is that i didn't feel like i was eating carbs - it's so light and fresh! (or is that my mind playing tricks on me?)

it comes in a pretty package. but as Ken M. succinctly put it, beware of the drippage! tip: eat to the side or layer up with paper napkins.

if you're still hungry after one savory crepe (i couldn't get through all of it), double fist it and tack on a sweet crepe with more of your favorite things.

like bananas. and nutella. and honey. and strawberries. 

mMmm. 

seating is not provided, but some easy go-tos nearby are the 2nd and mission public lobby (for those windy days) or the Orrick deck (for sunny days!). 

to many more perfect lunches. see you soon!

ps. love the new location!
author: Diana L.

description: I love this Crepe truck...   my favorite is a make-your-own with tomatoes, spinach, green onion, avocado, bacon and jack cheese.   YUM.   I've also tried the turkey cranberry and that was very good too.   I try to go before the lunch rush, have never had to wait long even when it is busy though.   Beware - it is cash only!
author: Cheryl B.

description:
I went here expecting "buckwheat crepes," which is what they advertise.  I have to limit my intake of gluten due to health reasons, so this sounded great.  Buckwheat doesn't have gluten.

I ordered my crepe... I wanted a chicken crepe.  I was told that the chicken is mixed with mushrooms and it's really good so I should just try it.  I say okay, though I think most of the time mushrooms are kind of gross.  Mushrooms inseparable from chicken: strike 1

I get my crepe.  It's hot on the outside and ICE COLD on the inside.  I'm talking, like, the chicken and mushroom mixture is still frozen in some parts.  Totally gross!   Also, the "chicken" is like mince meat.  It's all chopped up really tiny and there were big fat chunks, too.  Out of desperation and hunger I ate a portion of my crepe anyway.  Bad quality and not fresh: strike 2 & 3.

At about 1/3 of the way through my crepey disappointment, I hear the woman in the cart talking to the couple after me who ask about the buckwheat batter..."Oh, it's a mixture of buckwheat and regular wheat flour."  Oh, that's nice to know: strike 4.

Skip this place if you can and go to Crepes a Go Go on 11th.  They use regular wheat flour, but their crepes are actually good and fresh.
author: Kate R.

description:
I work in the Financial District and make the walk to St Germain about twice a week. They are fantastic!! I always get a sweet and a savory and have never been disappointed. Besides great, made to order food, you are greeted by the sweetest woman. No sure if she is the owner or not, but my guess is she must be. I can't imagine someone being so freindly without having a vested interest in return clients. Return I do! 
Do yourself a favor and go grab a crepe (or two, like I do. Current fave the ratatouille w/goat cheese and a Rasperry for dessert). Amazing!!
author: Steven C.

description: I had the Greek crepe. I liked how light the crepe tasted--must be because of the buckwheat. It was a good amount of food for lunch. I liked the type of crepe I chose, but I think I would like to try others, like the sweet crepes as well (nutella is the death of me)! For the Greek crepe, it seemed less hearty than my coworker's Mediterranean crepe. Nonetheless, the quantity and quality was still good.
author: Vera W.

description:
I made my first visit to Creperie Saint Germain last night and it knocked my socks off. I spend 10 weeks in France ever year and crepes are one of my main staple foods when I'm there. The crepe I had last night at the Creperie Saint Germain was better than any crepes I've had in Paris (and better than the crepes I've had in Brittany, where the French crepe was born). 

I am a fan of the savory crepe, and last night I had my first crepe at CSG--with ground beef, generous avocado, sour cream, fresh tomatoes (it was their daily special). It was just perfect. I shared it with my friends and we were all blown away! Prior to visiting CSG, my fave crepe place had been the crepevine. I like the crepevine, but the crepes at CSG were better--not as heavy. The crepe itself is like a fresh French crepe, but the fillings are generous, fresh, and all round it was just the perfect crepe.

I went at about 12:30 at night, there was no line, and Zee made the crepe in under 5 minutes. She is a great sales person and superfriendly.  I guess they are soon opening 2 more locations.  Totally the ideal food when you are leaving the bar and have the late-night munchies.
author: Betsy C.

description:
The crepes are delicious and the service is top notch!  So why only 4 stars instead of 5?  Word has clearly spread around the neighborhood about how good they are and they've become a bit of a victim of their own success.  It's a cart so they have limited space, which means only two griddles for crepes and that means sometimes (not all the time) you can have a bit of a wait.  But when that happens they offer you a free drink (today it was fresh lemonade!) while you're waiting.

If Yelp had a 4.5 star rating I'd give them that.  I go there at least once/week so obviously their food is worth the wait.
author: Regan F.

description: My friend and i shared the chicken crepe. dude, this place was totally what i wanted at 1:30am. until she hit a piece of bone. and then 3 min later, i gnawed down on a really large piece of bone. i had 3 drinks (a good quantity for me)--so probs a touch paranoid--but i'm gonna be worried about my teeth until morning.
author: grace l.

description: Went to the one on Market and Sansome this morning.  The guy was too busy talking about music with his hipster friend to take my order.  I finally got his attention and told him what I wanted.  He then went back to talking about music until I got his attention again and gestured thet he might want to start making the order.  He handed it to me about a minute later and I walked off.  I got half a block away and realized the egg was still clear liquid, totally raw.  I went back to find him, of course, talkin' Latin pop with his buddy.  He offered me my money back and I took it.  As I walked off I realized he had given me $4.50 back on a $6.50 order.
author: Justin C.

description: It's not the best crepes I've had and for the prices that CSG charges I would've expected more. I ordered strawberries with Creme fraiche- it was mediocre. Nothing that blew my mind. However, i did enjoy the friendly staff and how quick the service was.
author: C M.

description: fast, cheap and super friendly. These crepes are moist, flexible and WARM!  Organic buckwheat creaps are the best. I just INHALED the turkey and cheese breakfast crepe. Deeeee-lish! Perfect to keep one warm on a drizzly cold day like today!
author: linda l.

description: Mehhh, not worth the wait.  I don't know what the big deal w/ the organic buckwheat ingredient is.  It didn't taste any different and didn't appeal any better to the eye.  I had the spinach mushroom and cheese savory crepe. It tasted okay, nothing special. The sweet crepe we ordered was the honey, almond, and banana crepe. That was really good, but the cook messed up our order and gave us the apple cinnamon one first. I probably won't come back here again.
author: Joy A.

description:
delicious
fast
inexpensive
close to my new office
author: Fred C.

description: A little shack on the corner you can almost miss the place. I ordered #37 which consisted of bananas, nutella, & strawberries (my typical crepe order no matter where I go).
